awd_titl_txt: CDI-TYPE II--COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH:  Using Algebraic Topology to Connect Models with Measurements in Complex Nonequilibrium Systems

por.por_cntn:
Many difficult challenges facing science and technology today are due to the spatiotemporal dynamics of large systems that are strongly driven far-from-equilibrium. Examples include the dynamics of the weather and oceans, reacting chemicals in solution, and fluid turbulence. These problems are often highly nonlinear with very complex dynamics. An outcome of this project is a quantitative link between experiments and theory using numerical simulations for the precise conditions of experiment. We have identified fluid convection as our problem of focus. We have conducted careful numerical simulations to probe fundamental features of the pattern formation and dynamics of fluid convection for the precise conditions of experiment. The numerical simulations provide a complete description of the flow field and dynamics.  We used the numerics to calculate insightful diagnostics that are currently inaccessible to experiments such as the Lyapuov vectors, Lyapunov exponents, and fractal dimension. We used these results to advance our understanding of the complex dynamics of nonequilibrium systems.  The rich data provided by the numerical simulations was used to develop new ideas from algebraic topology to begin building the tools for use on much more complex systems where experiments and numerics are not possible.  This research supported the training of one PhD student in the field of computational science and engineering. The PhD student learned state-of-the-art numerical and theoretical techniques and also gained valuable experience in working as a member of a team on a large project that addressed difficult and broad challenges. The PI also used portions of this research as important examples of current challenges in an advanced graduate course called Chaos and Nonlinear Dynamics. This course has received broad and continued interest with a typical enrollment including graduate students from five or more departments across the Colleges of Engineering and Science at Virginia Tech. Lastly, this project made significant progress in developing the tools that will be used in the years to come by future scientists and engineers to push forward in building our physical understanding of the dynamics of large systems driven far-from-equilibrium.
